answers.body_markdown:
You do something like this in the `Pre-request Script` sandbox:

    let idGuid = pm.variables.replaceIn('{{$guid}}')
    let passwordGuid = pm.variables.replaceIn('{{$guid}}')
    
    pm.variables.set("id" , idGuid.replace(/-/g, ''))
    pm.variables.set("password" , passwordGuid.replace(/-/g, ''))

These would then resolve the variables that you have placed within the `request body`. 

Not the most efficient solution but it would create the values you would like.

There are also a number of other fake data variables available for you to use in the application:

https://learning.getpostman.com/docs/postman/scripts/postman_sandbox_api_reference/#dynamic-variables

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Non-body HTTP method cannot contain @Body

This means your @GET or @DELETE should not have @Body parameter. You can use query type url or path type url or Query Map to fulfill your need. Else you can use other method annotation.
answers.title: How to send request body in get method retrofit

answers.body_markdown:
GET method does not contain body like the POST does. Here you can learn more about REST methods: https://restfulapi.net/http-methods/

EDIT: I see that you said that it works in Postman so take a look at this:

***CAN GET request have a body?**

In other words, any HTTP request message is allowed to contain a message body, and thus must parse messages with that in mind. Server semantics for GET, however, are restricted such that a body, if any, has no semantic meaning to the request. ... Yes, you can send a request body with GET but it should not have any meaning.*

I found hack for this problem. My main purpose was to pass the input to the console application using a program. Since i cannot capture the ```stdin``` and pass the input, i thought of mimicking key press. I used 'pyautogui' for this.
```
import subprocess
from subprocess import run,call,PIPE,Popen
import time
from pyautogui import press

with Popen(["CommandProgram.exe"],stdout=PIPE,encoding = 'UTF-8') as process:
    print('Writing the command')
    time.sleep(2)
    #out,err = process.communicate('help')
    out = process.stdout.readline()
    process.stdout.flush()
    press('h')
    press('e')
    press('l')
    press('p')
    press('enter')
    for line in process.stdout :
        print(line)
    process.stdout.flush()
    press('r')
    press('u')
    press('n')
    press('enter')    
    for line in process.stdout :
        print(line)
```

answers.body_markdown:
You could use a correlated subquery with a `NOT EXISTS` condition to ensure that another record exists with the same `TransactionId` and `Amount`:

    SELECT TransactionId ,Amount , Account, CrDr
    FROM Table1 t
    WHERE EXISTS (
        SELECT 1
    	FROM Table1 t1
    	WHERE 
    	    t.id <> t1.id 
    	    AND t.TransactionId = t1.TransactionId
    		AND t.Amount = t1.Amount
    )
    ORDER BY TransactionId  ASC,Amount  ASC, CrDr ASC

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=sqlserver_2017&fiddle=471040738b7ba4eb553727a6cedada9c)**:

<pre>
TransactionId | Amount | Account | CrDr
------------: | -----: | ------: | ---:
            1 |    100 |   11111 |    1
            1 |    100 |   12111 |    2
            2 |    130 |   13133 |    1
            2 |    130 |   13233 |    2
</pre>

answers.body_markdown:
Basically both of them represent [affine transform][1]. However `SimilarityTransform` is used to compute this transformation between two sets of points and `warpAffine` is used to transform image using affine transformation. The OpenCV's equivalent to `SimilarityTransform` is `getAffineTransform`. You can find more information regarding these functions [here][2].


  [1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affine_transformation
  [2]: https://docs.opencv.org/3.4/d4/d61/tutorial_warp_affine.html
answers.title: Difference between SimilarityTransform (scikit-image) and warpAffine (openCV)?

answers.body_markdown:
A [similarity transform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_(geometry)#In_Euclidean_space) is a special case of an [affine transform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affine_transformation), in which the shear is 0. (Only scale, rotation, and translation are allowed.) scikit-image also has an AffineTransform object.

The transform objects in scikit-image can be used both to estimate the transform, as pointed out by Piotr, but also to perform the transform, using [`skimage.transform.warp`](https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.transform.html#skimage.transform.warp).
answers.title: Difference between SimilarityTransform (scikit-image) and warpAffine (openCV)?

It uses both scikit-image `SimilarityTransform` function ([documentation](https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.transform.html#skimage.transform.SimilarityTransform)) and openCV `warpAffine` function ([documentation](https://docs.opencv.org/2.4/modules/imgproc/doc/geometric_transformations.html#warpaffine))

answers.body_markdown:
Some of them really are identical – i.e. just aliases for the purpose of convenience.
E.g. `gnp_random_graph` = `binomial_graph` = `erdos_renyi_graph`.

They all generate the same type of graph but some use different algorithms that perform better or worse depending on the parameters/properties of your graph (size, density, ...). So there is no single best choice. (Even if there were, it may be of academic interest to some people to also have alternate algorithms available – e.g. for speed comparisons.)

Some also differ in the way you define/paramerterize your graph. E.g. Some use the number of nodes and the probability to grow an edge, while others are defined by the number of nodes and the number of edges.

Depending on your application one may be preferable to the other.

You can not specify dynamic parameters on your OAuth redirect URL.

But you can still redirect the user to a dynamic URL after authentication. Instead of putting the document ID in the URL, put it in the current server session. Then once the request returns from Slack to your app just get the document ID from the current session and redirect the user.

Should be straight forward since you need to use server sessions anyways to verify the OAuth `state` for security purposes.

answers.body_markdown:
You might have seen [this community thread][1], many users are affected by this behavior. That may be [the intended behavior by Microsoft][2]. 

See the comments from [code sample][3]:

    //Extract the tracing service for use in debugging sandboxed plug-ins.
    ITracingService tracingService =
        (ITracingService)serviceProvider.GetService(typeof(ITracingService));

But interestingly [MS documentation conflicts with that][4]. 

>Tracing is supported for sandboxed (partial trust) and full trust registered custom code and during synchronous or asynchronous execution.

Probably [this idea][5] will make the change, vote for it.


  [1]: https://community.dynamics.com/crm/f/microsoft-dynamics-crm-forum/189346/plugin-trace-log-not-working-on-dynamics-crm-2016-on-premise
  [2]: http://blog.intocrm.net/plug-in-trace-logs-outside-the-sandbox-2/
  [3]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/dynamicscrm-2016/developers-guide/gg328574(v=crm.8)?redirectedfrom=MSDN#write-to-the-tracing-service

answers.body_markdown:
This is because you are running Python 2. Note that there are some significant differences around division between Python 2.X and Python 3.X

    > python2.7
    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> np.pmt(rate=((1+0.07)**(1/12) - 1), nper=15*12, pv=0, fv=1000000)
    -5555.5555555555557
   
    > python3
    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> np.pmt(rate=((1+0.07)**(1/12) - 1), nper=15*12, pv=0, fv=1000000)
    -3214.351338524575


If you still want to use Python 2.X, you just have to change `(1/12)` to `(1/12.0)`:

    > python2.7
    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> np.pmt(rate=((1+0.07)**(1/12.0) - 1), nper=15*12, pv=0, fv=1000000)
    -3214.3513385245751

answers.body_markdown:
Looking at [Package: nginx](https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/nginx) and following [nginx-full](https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/nginx-full) or [nginx-light](https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/nginx-light) shows, that architecture i386 is still supported in Bionic.

So your problem must be something else.

---

From your comment, it looks like you have http://nginx.org/packages/ubuntu/ added as a repository in either `/etc/apt/sources.list` or some file in `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/`. From http://nginx.org/packages/ubuntu/dists/bionic/Release, it seems that i386 indeed is not supported

>Architectures: amd64 arm64

Looking for an entry

    grep nginx.org /etc/apt/sources.list /etc/apt/sources.list.d/*

should reveal, which is the relevant file. Comment the appropriate line (prefix with a `#`) or remove it, then do an

    apt-get update

and reinstall the package directly from the Ubuntu repository.

answers.body_markdown:
The data payload to `BigQuery.Jobs.insert()` has to be a blob. 

You can create that blob from either CSV content or a [newline delimited JSON][1]. Newline delimited JSON is a distinct form of JSON that is [required by BigQuery][2]. It is not natively supported by Apps Script. However, you should be able to convert standard JSON to that format by creating a custom [`replacer` function and passing it as a parameter to `JSON.stringify()`][3]. Alternatively, you might be able to leverage an existing Javascript library (you might be able to find something via NPM or just doing a search on Github).

Once you've generated a newline delimited JSON (as either a string or a byte array) you'll need to convert it to a blob using `Utilities.newBlob()` and pass it to the `BigQuery.Jobs.insert()` method.


  [1]: http://jsonlines.org/
  [2]: https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/loading-data-cloud-storage-json
  [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/JSON/stringify#The_replacer_parameter

Define compression at the tablespace level, then when you create your tables in development, don't include any of the storage elements, just let their TABLESPACE characteristics take affect.

Barring that, you're going to have two sets of DDL scripts for source control, one for development, and another for production.
answers.title: Oracle database 12c "compress for query" OPTION

items.body_markdown:
I have a development server on a simple server with oracle 12c and our production server is on Oracle Exadata.

On some of the tables we use COMPRESS FOR QUERY option.
My problem is every time we create a table we need to remove this option(from DDL) for development and put it when we deploy changes on production.

Is there any option at database level to use the option on development server also, even if the server is not exadata(something like skiping it) ?

Thank you.
items.title: Oracle database 12c "compress for query" OPTION

answers.body_markdown:
Logging frameworks such as slf4j or log4j2 have an API component and a run-time component. Your code should depend only on the API component. It is the run-time component that you should avoid specifying when you deploy to a particular environment as that environment may have its own version of that run-time component. In your example, libraries such as log4j-to-slf4j , log4j-api are API components. It is ok for them to be present in the WAR. However you should ensure that your environment is providing a compatible runtime logging component. 

See the explanation for 'provided' scope here : https://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html#Dependency_Scope

answers.body_markdown:
Move this `P_LIST.append(newdict)` after except condition and before `print("-----------------------------------")`

The value of P_LIST in above code is getting updated in second try except case and if that try except fails you will not get any value appended in P_LIST. 

(Suggestion) Also add some debug logs in your code for better debugging in future.

answers.body_markdown:
The block of configuration you posted is a "resource routing", which means it's a special routing handled by Sylius to generate CRUD routing for a given resource automatically. More information about this can be found in the [documentation of the ResourceBundle about routings][1].

For the list page, it uses a grid, which is specified in the configuration you posted.

What you need is to [extend and modify the configuration of the grid][2].  
You can find  the base configuration for [this grid here][3].

For your case, the simplest way would be to override the method used to "select" the payments.
```yml
repository:
    method: createListQueryBuilder # <== Change this one
```
Then extend the `Repository` for the `Payment` resource and create your new function in it which will just add the correct `where` to the query builder used by the grid.

More information about extending the repository [can be found here][4].

Hope this helps :)

  [1]: https://docs.sylius.com/en/1.6/components_and_bundles/bundles/SyliusResourceBundle/routing.html
  [2]: https://docs.sylius.com/en/1.6/customization/grid.html
  [3]: https://github.com/Sylius/Sylius/blob/master/src/Sylius/Bundle/AdminBundle/Resources/config/grids/shipment.yml
  [4]: https://docs.sylius.com/en/1.6/customization/repository.html

items.body_markdown:
I have some C# code that is an API client using HttpClient and you can access it via cmdlets in a binary PowerShell module I have. Although this is a code website, I think it is irrelevant to show it here, because it works fine on Windows Desktop and the full Desktop version of Windows Server. However, when I run commands that require any URL rewriting i.e. "/" to "%2F", I receive a 404 error - url not found on Windows Server Core. Naturally, the code is doing this fine and I am printing it to screen before the Post call is made to prove it is the same one I see on Windows 10, Windows 2016 (Full version), the API explorer and in Postman. On Windows Server Core something seems to happen after this point that breaks the url.

To prove it wasn't just something strange in my code, I tried examples using the old WebClient in PowerShell, and Invoke-RestMethod (including the -UseBasicParsing switch), and then tried both of them on Windows Server Core 2016 AND 2019. Same problem each time on the Windows Server Core servers - `The requested URL was not found`.

The only think I can think of is that the lack of applications like Internet Explorer may have some bearing on this. In other articles people have suggested the `-UseBasicParsing` switch in Invoke-RestMethod is meant to account for that, but it hasn't worked here.

Has anyone experienced anything similar and is there anything I can do about this other than just run the tasks from a full desktop version of Windows Server?

EDIT:

I've since found the issue exists on the full version of Server 2016 too. A fresh instance of 2019 seems to work. I will probably log a ticket with the vendor of the API to get some support on the inconsistent responses.
